messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Exponential tractability of ùêø‚ÇÇ-approximation with function values

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We study the complexity of high-dimensional approximation in the L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}-norm when different classes of information are available; we compare the power of function evaluations with the power of arbtirary continuous linear measurements. Here, we discuss the situation when the number of linear measurements required to achieve an error Œµ‚àà(0,1)ùúÄ01\varepsilon\in(0,1) in dimension d‚àà‚Ñïùëë‚Ñïd\in\mathbb{N} depends only poly-logarithmically on Œµ‚àí1superscriptùúÄ1\varepsilon^{-1}. This corresponds to an exponential order of convergence of the approximation error, which often happens in applications. However, it does not mean that the high-dimensional approximation problem is easy, the main difficulty usually lies within the dependence on the dimension dùëëd. We determine to which extent the required amount of information changes if we allow only function evaluation instead of arbitrary linear information. It turns out that in this case we only lose very little, and we can even restrict to linear algorithms. In particular, several notions of tractability hold simultaneously for both types of available information. Keywords. Approximation, Multivariate problems, Tractability, Complexity

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A stability barrier for reconstructions from Fourier samples",
        "On the numerical stability of Fourier extensions",
        "Optimal sampling rates for approximating analytic functions from pointwise samples",
        "Convergence rates for greedy algorithms in reduced basis methods",
        "A priori convergence of the greedy algorithm for the parametrized reduced basis method",
        "Linear vs. nonlinear algorithms for linear problems",
        "Estimates for n-widths of sets of smooth functions on complex spheres",
        "Approximation of analytic functions in Korobov spaces",
        "A sharp upper bound for sampling numbers in L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}",
        "Hyperbolic Cross Approximation",
        "Tractability of approximation in the weighted Korobov space in the worst-case setting ‚Äì a complete picture",
        "On dimension-independent rates of convergence for function approximation with Gaussian kernels",
        "Neue Herleitung und explizite Restabsch√§tzung der Riemann-Siegel-Formel",
        "On tensor product approximation of analytic functions",
        "Convergence rates of the pod‚Äìgreedy method",
        "Tensor-product approximation to operators and functions in high dimensions",
        "Nonlinear approximation using Gaussian kernels",
        "Random sections of ellipsoids and the power of random information",
        "Lower bounds for the error of quadrature formulas for Hilbert spaces",
        "On weak tractability of the Clenshaw‚ÄìCurtis Smolyak algorithm",
        "The curse of dimensionality for numerical integration of smooth functions",
        "Product rules are optimal for numerical integration in classical smoothness spaces",
        "The curse of dimensionality for numerical integration on general domains",
        "Approximation in Hermite spaces of smooth functions",
        "Tractability of multivariate approximation defined over Hilbert spaces with exponential weights",
        "Worst-case optimal approximation with increasingly flat Gaussian kernels",
        "Uniform recovery of high-dimensional Crsuperscriptùê∂ùëüC^{r}-functions",
        "Function values are enough for L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}-approximation",
        "Function values are enough for L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}-approximation: Part II",
        "Simple characterizations of exponential tractability for linear multivariate problems",
        "s-numbers in information-based complexity",
        "A new upper bound for sampling numbers",
        "Tractability of multivariate problems. Vol. 1: Linear information, volume 6 of EMS Tracts in Mathematics",
        "Approximation of infinitely differentiable multivariate functions is intractable",
        "Tractability of multivariate problems. Volume II: Standard information for functionals, volume 12 of EMS Tracts in Mathematics",
        "Tractability of multivariate problems. Volume III: Standard information for operators, volume 18 of EMS Tracts in Mathematics",
        "Tractability of multivariate problems for standard and linear information in the worst case setting: part i",
        "Operator ideals",
        "Impossibility of fast stable approximation of analytic functions from equispaced samples",
        "A variant of Schur‚Äôs product theorem and its applications",
        "Multivariate approximation for analytic functions with Gaussian kernels",
        "Approximation of periodic functions",
        "Multivariate Approximation, volume 32 of Cambridge Monographs on Applied and Computational Mathematics",
        "On the worst-case error of least squares algorithms for L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}-approximation with high probability",
        "Scattered data approximation, volume 17 of Cambridge Monographs on Applied and Computational Mathematics",
        "On weak tractability of the Smolyak algorithm for approximation problems",
        "A note on EC-tractability of multivariate approximation in weighted Korobov spaces for the standard information class"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Exponential tractability of ùêø‚ÇÇ-approximation with function values, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
